title: 107_hr5113
content: The Act titled "Rural Health Training Incentive Act" encourages health professionals to practice in rural areas through demonstration programs. This Act is an amendment to Part B of title VII of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can award grants to 5 accredited schools of medicine or nursing to run a program encouraging health professionals to work in rural areas. The funds must be used for developing and improving programs to attract youth in rural areas to health professions, training needed professionals in rural areas, and expanding rural training networks. The Secretary can award grants to 5 accredited schools of medicine or nursing to promote rural health workforce. Priority is given to schools with rural training programs in family medicine and nursing specialties. The Secretary prioritizes accredited schools with rural training programs and a comprehensive approach to addressing health profession shortages in rural areas. Applicants must provide non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of the costs for the demonstration program. The Secretary awards grants to accredited schools with rural training programs for a 3-year period. Non-Federal contributions must be at least 50% of the costs, and may be in cash or in kind. Federal contributions or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included in the non-Federal contributions. The Secretary awards grants to accredited schools with rural training programs for a 3-year period. Schools of nursing must be accredited by specific organizations. A report on the effectiveness of the programs in addressing healthcare professional shortages in rural areas is required. $20,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2005.
